Edgar F. Codd

General

Edgar Codd was born in Fortuneswell, England in 1923. He won a Turing Award in 1981 for his work on relational models to aid database management which was revolutionary.

Contributions

Codd studied mathematics and chemistry at Exeter College in Oxford. After his studies he participated in WW2 as a pilot for the Royal Air Force Coastal Command.
In 1948 Codd moved to the US to work as a mathematical programmer at IBM. He worked there until 1980 but throughout the years Codd moved to Ontario Canada in 1953, to Ann-Arbor in 1957 and then to San Jose in California in 1959.
While in IBM Codd worked on various projects, one of which won him a Turing Award.
In Ann-Arbor, where he was doing his PhD at the university of Michigan, he made his thesis about self-replication in cellular automata contributing to the work of Von Neumann.
In San Jose, Codd worked on theories of data arrangement. His paper "A Relational Model of Data for Large Shared Data Banks" explained all his ideas about relational models and how they can be implemented for database management. IBM did not implement his model until the customers pressured for implementations. Nevertheless when IBM created the project System R which was based on the ideas of Codd he put other people working on it without the expertise of Cobb and the end product was very different from Codd’s ideas. The project even used a different language called SEQUEL which was non-relational opposite to Alpha, Codd’s language.
Separately from the team, Codd worked on his own relational model with the help of Christopher J. Date.
In the 80s where relational models were gaining traction, Codd found problems of companies misusing the name relational models and so as a response he wrote his 12 rules that explained what constitutes as relational programming and what not.
After this, working at IBM became impossible so he left and started his own company with Christopher Date and other computer scientists.
Edgar Codd also coined the term Online Analytical Processing alongside which he wrote a corresponding book, "twelve laws of online analytical processing".
For the last years of his life Codd moved to his home in Florida, where he died in 2003 from heart failure at the age of 79.

Award 1981

In memory of A.M. Turing
